title: Brave Browser permanently timestamps & logs connection times for all v2 domains ~/.config/BraveSoftware/Brave-Browser/tor/data/tor.log
vulnerability_information:
## Summary:

A vulnerability in the Brave Browser v1.28.43 and below allows a local or physical attacker to view the exact timestamps that a user connected to a v2 onion address. A local or physical attacker could read  ~/.config/BraveSoftware/Brave-Browser/tor/data/tor.log identify the exact moment a user connected to a new site, easily triangulating the user via a complete log of connection timestamps, which could be easily compared with a server connection log, a compromised Tor end point, or other related Tor attack, affecting the confidentiality & integrity of a user's Tor session.

## Products affected: 

 * operating system, Brave version or Brave website page, etc.

Tor Desktop Browser (All platforms)

## Steps To Reproduce:

 * List the steps needed to reproduce the vulnerability

Visit http://wikitoronionlinks.com/ while using Tor Private Browsing.

Click on an assortment of .onion v2 URLs.

Inspect `~/.config/BraveSoftware/Brave-Browser/tor/data/tor.log`

## Supporting Material/References:

activities.message:
thanks for the report. i would actually suggest opening this as an issue with Tor project since this also affects tor browser. https://gitlab.torproject.org/tpo/applications/tor-browser/-/issues

as for brave i think we should just reduce LogTimeGranularity. we definitely still want to log messages that are warn or error. maybe tor project should change this warning to a notice and brave should stop logging notices.
actually we do need notice messages for tor bootstrapping issues

Thanks for the quick response!

I just repeated the process on Tor's Tor and cannot find any logging to disk.

Inside of `tor.log`, Brave stores the warnings, along with probably a some other info that shouldn't be there,

May I suggest disabling Tor logging by default?

Also, for the score, I was basing it off of the last one, which NIST gave a 5.5: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2020-8276

I think this one is significantly more detailed logging than the first vulnerability, including:

```
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] Tor 0.4.5.8 opening new log file.
Jul 01 08:40:15.005 [notice] We compiled with OpenSSL 101010bf: OpenSSL 1.1.1k  25 Mar 2021 and we are running with OpenSSL 101010bf: 1.1.1k. These two versions should be binary compatible.
Jul 01 08:40:15.008 [notice] Tor 0.4.5.8 running on Linux with Libevent 2.1.11-stable, OpenSSL 1.1.1k, Zlib 1.2.11, Liblzma N/A, Libzstd N/A and Glibc 2.31 as libc.
Jul 01 08:40:15.008 [notice] Tor can't help you if you use it wrong! Learn how to be safe at https://www.torproject.org/download/download#warning
Jul 01 08:40:15.008 [notice] Configuration file "/nonexistent" not present, using reasonable defaults.
Jul 01 08:40:15.010 [notice] Opening Socks listener on 127.0.0.1:0
Jul 01 08:40:15.010 [notice] Socks listener listening on port 33083.
Jul 01 08:40:15.010 [notice] Opened Socks listener connection (ready) on 127.0.0.1:33083
Jul 01 08:40:15.010 [notice] Opening Control listener on 127.0.0.1:0
Jul 01 08:40:15.010 [notice] Control listener listening on port 33261.
Jul 01 08:40:15.010 [notice] Opened Control listener connection (ready) on 127.0.0.1:33261
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 0% (starting): Starting
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] Starting with guard context "default"
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] New control connection opened from 127.0.0.1.
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] Tor 0.4.5.8 opening log file.
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 5% (conn): Connecting to a relay
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 10% (conn_done): Connected to a relay
Jul 01 08:40:15.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 14% (handshake): Handshaking with a relay
Jul 01 08:40:16.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 15% (handshake_done): Handshake with a relay done
Jul 01 08:40:16.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 20% (onehop_create): Establishing an encrypted directory connection
Jul 01 08:40:16.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 25% (requesting_status): Asking for networkstatus consensus
Jul 01 08:40:17.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 30% (loading_status): Loading networkstatus consensus
Jul 01 08:40:19.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 45% (requesting_descriptors): Asking for relay descriptors
Jul 01 08:40:19.000 [notice] I learned some more directory information, but not enough to build a circuit: We need more microdescriptors: we have 2289/6839, and can only build 5% of likely paths. (We have 39% of guards bw, 37% of midpoint bw, and 35% of exit bw = 5% of path bw.)
Jul 01 08:40:20.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 52% (loading_descriptors): Loading relay descriptors
Jul 01 08:40:22.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 58% (loading_descriptors): Loading relay descriptors
Jul 01 08:40:22.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 65% (loading_descriptors): Loading relay descriptors
Jul 01 08:40:22.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 70% (loading_descriptors): Loading relay descriptors
Jul 01 08:40:23.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 75% (enough_dirinfo): Loaded enough directory info to build circuits
Jul 01 08:40:23.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 90% (ap_handshake_done): Handshake finished with a relay to build circuits
Jul 01 08:40:23.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 95% (circuit_create): Establishing a Tor circuit
Jul 01 08:40:24.000 [notice] Bootstrapped 100% (done): Done
Jul 01 08:40:24.000 [warn] Invalid hostname [scrubbed]; rejecting
Jul 01 08:40:25.000 [warn] Invalid hostname [scrubbed]; rejecting
Jul 01 08:40:30.000 [warn] Invalid hostname [scrubbed]; rejecting
```

Namely the following:

```
Jul 01 14:40:15.000 [notice] While bootstrapping, fetched this many bytes: 633885 (consensus network-status fetch); 2098104 (microdescriptor fetch)
Jul 01 14:40:15.000 [notice] While not bootstrapping, fetched this many bytes: 150535 (consensus network-status fetch)
Jul 01 14:40:15.000 [notice] Average packaged cell fullness: 78.503%. TLS write overhead: 4%
Jul 01 17:17:55.000 [notice] Catching signal TERM, exiting cleanly.
```
thanks we are looking into getting rid of the log file

Thank you very much for the score update 😁

Removing the tor log is a great idea, or at least disabling it by default would be nice, since it’s quite verbose.

Could we get a CVE issued for this one too once the tor log is removed? I think It would encourage end users to immediately upgrade to latest release once fixed.

Alternatively, could simply:

- disable tor logging by default (switch to opt-in only for debugging)
- rm/delete/shred the log file on exit

Although Tor Project’s Tor doesn’t log to disk, it still logs to memory, so I will raise a private issue to the Tor project as well.

Thanks again!
https://github.com/brave/brave-core/pull/9346 has been merged. planning on uplifting to beta release soon and then we can ask for a CVE ID.

Thank you very much! <3

FYI: Tor project closed the report regarding v2 connection timestamps as informative and will not be removing the timestamps.
CVE-2021-22929 has been requested. I'll disclose this report soon after 1.28.x reaches stable.
Thanks @diracdeltas, I saw a few releases and assumed it was already mainline. Take your time :)

Thank you very much @diracdeltas!

The CVE ID is still listed as None, and I did reach out to MITRE but as H1 is the CNA, I wasn't able to add references.

Would you be able to add these to the references on the advisory for CVE-2021-22929?

https://github.com/brave/brave-core/pull/9346

https://hackerone.com/reports/1249056

https://www.privacyaffairs.com/cve-2021-22929-brave-tor-vulnerability/

https://github.com/sickcodes/security/blob/master/advisories/SICK-2021-109.md

https://sick.codes/sick-2021-109
I cannot edit it either and it says "pending hackerone approval". @jgarza are you able to edit the CVE request?
I emailed support and they published the CVE, thank you @diracdeltas!
